node.title: Robberies are becoming an increasing concern for retailers.
node.alt: A security guard outside the Nordstrom store at the Grove retail and entertainment complex in Los Angeles on Tuesday. A group smashed windows at the department store on Monday.
node.description: About 69 percent of stores said they have seen an increase in organized theft in the past year.
node.content: ["Retailers are expressing more concerns about robberies this year.", "Best Buy said this week that its business was facing new pressure from organized crimes and thefts, and it was implementing new security measures in certain areas. One tactic includes putting QR codes on products behind lock-and-key. That allows customers to scan the codes and then check out, so associates don\u2019t need to unlock the items right away.", "\u201cWe are finding ways where we can lock up product, but still make that a good customer experience,\u201d Corie Barry, Best Buy\u2019s chief executive, said on an earnings call on Tuesday. \u201cIn some instances, we\u2019re hiring security. We\u2019re working with our vendors on creative ways we can stage the product.\u201d", "Still, she said, the pressure was visible in the company\u2019s financials \u2014 she named it as one reason Best Buy saw a decline in its profit margin rate \u2014 and \u201ctraumatizing for our associates.\u201d", "About 69 percent of retailers said they had seen an increase in organized retail crimes in the past year, pointing to factors including the pandemic, policing, changes to sentencing guidelines and the growth of online marketplaces, according to a recent retail security survey from the National Retail Federation, an industry trade group. Respondents said that the groups involved have become more aggressive and violent.", "This month, a group of about 80 people rushed into a Nordstrom store in Walnut Creek, Calif., outside San Francisco, and stole merchandise, with many escaping in speeding cars. There were also \u201csmash-and-grab\u201d robberies at other retailers in San Francisco around the same time, including Louis Vuitton, Saint Laurent and Burberry, according to The San Francisco Chronicle.", "\u201cOur priority has always been and will remain the safety of our people, whether that\u2019s the pandemic, whether that is unruly customers, whether that is outright theft, which is a great deal of what we\u2019re seeing right now,\u201d Ms. Barry said this week. \u201cThis is a real issue that hurts and scares real people.\u201d"]
